section_title: Variables and Data Types in Python
section_description: A hands-on programming section that introduces the fundamental building blocks of Python: variables and data types. Students will learn how to store, manipulate, and understand different kinds of data through practical coding exercises.
learning_objectives: Define and assign values to variables using Python syntax.
Identify and use core data types including integers, floats, strings, and booleans.
Convert data between different types using explicit type casting.
Apply variables and data types to solve basic computational problems.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create variables, assign values to them, and print their contents to the console.
key_topics: Variable assignment syntax using the equals sign (=)
Naming conventions and rules for valid variable names
Using the print() function to display variable values
Reassigning new values to existing variables

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create variables to store your name, age, and favorite color. Print each variable on a separate line.
Create a variable called 'message' with the value 'Hello'. Print it. Then reassign it to 'Goodbye' and print it again.

lessons.lesson_title: Working with Numbers: Integers and Floats
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to perform basic arithmetic operations with numeric data types and identify the difference between integers and floats.
key_topics: Integer and float data types
Basic arithmetic operators (+, -, *, /)
Exponentiation (**) and modulo (%) operators
Determining the type of a variable with the type() function

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create two variables with numeric values. Perform and print the result of addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division operations on them.
Store a circle's radius in a variable. Calculate and print its area (πr²) and circumference (2πr). Use 3.14 for π.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to create string variables, use string methods, and combine strings through concatenation.
key_topics: Defining strings with single and double quotes
String concatenation using the plus (+) operator
Common string methods: .upper(), .lower(), .title()
Using f-strings for string formatting

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user for their city and country (using input()). Create a single string in the format 'City, Country' and print it in uppercase.
Store a person's name in a variable. Use an f-string to create a message like 'Hello [name], welcome to Python!' and print it.

lessons.lesson_title: Making Decisions with Booleans and Comparisons
lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to use comparison operators to create Boolean values and predict the outcome of logical expressions.
key_topics: Boolean data type (True, False)
Comparison operators (==, !=, >, <, >=, <=)
Logical operators (and, or, not)
Using comparisons to control program flow with basic if statements

exercises.exercise_instructions: Create two variables with numbers. Write print statements that check if the first is greater than, equal to, and less than the second.
Set a predefined username and password. Check if a user-inputted username and password match the predefined values and print 'Access granted' or 'Access denied'.

lessons.lesson_objective: Students will be able to convert data between strings, integers, and floats using type casting functions.
key_topics: Type casting functions: str(), int(), float()
Converting user input (which is always a string) to numbers
Handling errors when conversion is impossible
Combining strings and numbers in output

exercises.exercise_instructions: Ask the user for their age. Convert the input to an integer and calculate how many days they have lived (approx. age * 365). Print the result as a full sentence.
Ask for the price of an item and the quantity purchased. Calculate the total cost. Print a receipt that combines text and the calculated numbers in a readable format.
